On November 5, 2021, Jacob Werner, Co-Head of Americas Acquisitions for Blackstone Real Estate, contacted Mr. Murphy indicating that Mr. Werner was going to be in Atlanta the following week and inquired as to whether Mr. Murphy had some time to catch-up. Mr. Murphy had planned to be in New York at the end of that week and suggested they meet at such time. On November 11, Messrs. Murphy and Werner had breakfast during which Mr. Werner stated that Blackstone was impressed with the Company and its Sunbelt platform and that Blackstone would like to explore a potential acquisition of the Company. He indicated that, based on its review of publicly available information, Blackstone believed it could acquire the Company at a significant premium to the Company’s current stock price. No specific terms of a potential transaction were discussed. Following the breakfast, Mr. Murphy telephoned Mr. McLure, our lead independent director, and the Company’s outside counsel, Vinson & Elkins LLP (“V&E”), to inform them of this conversation. On November 10, 2021, the closing price of our common stock was $13.87 per share. On November 22, 2021, Mr. Werner contacted Mr. Murphy and requested a time to follow up on their prior conversation. Mr. Murphy suggested waiting until after Thanksgiving. Mr. Murphy informed Mr. McLure and V&E of this outreach and, with the approval of Mr. McLure, called Goldman Sachs for advice. Mr. Murphy contacted Goldman Sachs based on its knowledge of and experience with the Company in light of having regularly advised us on a range of matters, including the sale of our office assets during 2021 and capital markets generally. On December 6, 2021, Mr. Werner asked Mr. Murphy whether he would be available to meet in Atlanta the next day. Mr. Murphy apprised Mr. McLure and representatives of V&E and Goldman Sachs of this request, and Mr. McLure authorized Mr. Murphy to meet with Mr. Werner. 31 On December 7, 2021, Messrs. Murphy and Werner met over breakfast in Atlanta during which time Mr. Werner reiterated Blackstone’s interest in exploring a potential acquisition of the Company. He indicated that Blackstone had devoted a substantial amount of time to analyzing the Company, that Blackstone had sufficient equity capital to complete a transaction and that Blackstone anticipated being able to pay $4 to $5 per share in cash above the Company’s then market price per share, but did not reference any other terms. He requested that the Company enter into a confidentiality agreement and provide non-public information in order for Blackstone to learn more about the Company so that it could provide a more specific proposal. Mr. Murphy noted that he was very confident in the Company’s standalone plan and the progress the Company had made over the last two years. Following this meeting, Mr. Murphy updated Mr. McLure and representatives of Goldman Sachs, V&E and King & Spalding LLP (“K&S”), outside counsel for the Company. Mr. Murphy asked Goldman Sachs to prepare preliminary financial analyses to assist our board of directors in deciding whether to pursue a potential transaction with Blackstone. On December 6, 2021, the closing price of the our common stock was $13.56 per share. On December 10, 2021, during a previously scheduled board of directors meeting, which was attended by John Isakson, our Chief Financial Officer, and a representative of V&E, Mr. Murphy summarized his discussions with Mr. Werner. The directors and Mr. Isakson discussed Blackstone’s desire to enter into a confidentiality agreement in order to review non-public information, as well as process and timing considerations if we were to engage in discussions with Blackstone, including the benefits and risks of reaching out to other potential acquirers. Following this discussion, the directors unanimously agreed that the best course of action would be to seek Goldman Sachs’ financial advice regarding a potential sale of the Company, as well as its views as to the best process to explore a sale, and other potential strategic alternatives for the Company. On December 15, 2021, as directed by our board of directors, Mr. Murphy contacted Mr. Werner to inform him that the Company was considering Blackstone’s interest in a transaction and would respond once our board of directors had decided how it would like to proceed, which would not be until after the first of the year. On December 20, 2021, our board of directors held a meeting with members of our management team and representatives of Goldman Sachs, V&E and K&S in attendance. A representative of V&E reviewed the directors’ duties under Maryland law in connection with a potential acquisition of the Company and provided an overview of a typical process for a public company merger transaction. The directors engaged in a discussion with Goldman Sachs regarding, among other things, Blackstone’s historical capital raising activities and available capital, Blackstone’s interest in multifamily properties located in the Sunbelt region as evidenced by Blackstone’s agreement to acquire Bluerock Residential Growth REIT, Inc. (“Bluerock”) announced earlier that day, the price Blackstone agreed to pay in the Bluerock transaction and the impact of such transaction on the price of our common stock, the potential treatment of our preferred stock in a transaction with Blackstone and whether the amount of preferred stock outstanding and leverage could impact the price per common share at which Blackstone might be willing to acquire the Company. After discussion, our board of directors requested that Goldman Sachs prepare a preliminary financial analysis of the Company and continue to analyze Blackstone’s potential interest in a transaction and other strategic alternatives for discussion at the next board of directors meeting. Following the board of directors meeting on December 20, 2021, the Company received a notice (the “nomination notice”) from Arkhouse Securities LLC and its affiliates Arkhouse Securities II and Arkhouse Partners LLC (collectively, “Arkhouse”) setting forth Arkhouse’s desire to replace five of the eight directors on the Company’s board of directors with five of its own named nominees and effectively obtain control of the Company through its nominees. Our board of directors was made aware of the nominations. Arkhouse’s outside counsel stated in the correspondence accompanying the nomination notice that Arkhouse intended to engage privately and constructively with the Company regarding its thoughts on opportunities to enhance value for our stockholders, but did not provide any detail on these opportunities. V&E initiated several phone calls and correspondence with Arkhouse’s outside counsel in December 2021 and January 2022 to determine the reason Arkhouse believed it needed to make nominations related to the Company’s 2022 annual meeting of shareholders (the “Annual Meeting”) and to schedule an initial meeting between the Company and Arkhouse. Given the deadline of December 22, 2021 for nominating directors for the Annual Meeting as set out in the Company’s proxy statement for its 2021 annual meeting, outside counsel for Arkhouse confirmed to V&E that Arkhouse had made nominations to retain optionality if it later believed it would be necessary to contest the election of five directors at the Annual Meeting. Arkhouse’s outside counsel did not express any underlying grievance or criticisms Arkhouse may have had that played any role in it submitting nominations. 32 On December 31, 2021, after the close of trading on the NYSE, Reuters published an article reporting that Arkhouse was seeking to take control of the Company and had nominated five individuals to serve as directors (the “Reuters Article”). On December 31, 2021, the closing price of our common stock was $18.06 per share. On January 5, 2022, Mr. Werner contacted a representative of Goldman Sachs to reiterate Blackstone’s interest in exploring a transaction with the Company, but did not provide any specific terms. On January 21, 2022, our board of directors held a meeting with members of our management team and representatives of Goldman Sachs, V&E and K&S in attendance. Mr. Murphy summarized the work that our management team and Goldman Sachs had performed regarding various strategic alternatives for the Company. A representative of V&E reviewed the directors’ duties under Maryland law in connection with a potential acquisition of the Company. Our management then reviewed and discussed with our board of directors a preliminary draft of our five-year projections for 2022 through 2026 and the assumptions used to prepare such projections. Representatives of Goldman Sachs discussed with our board of directors their preliminary financial analysis of the Company as well as other strategic alternatives that might be available to the Company, including remaining a standalone independent public company or selling certain or all of our grocery-anchored retail assets. A discussion ensued among the directors, management, our outside counsel and financial advisor regarding, among other things, the benefits and risks related to each of the potential strategic alternatives; indicative capitalization rates from recent transactions in the REIT industry; the substantial amount of our preferred stock and debt, including significant property level debt; our need to frequently raise capital due to the capital-intensive nature of our business; the cost of obtaining capital; and challenges of acquiring multifamily properties on an accretive basis in the current environment. Our board of directors also discussed with management and our advisors the benefits and risks of to the Company and its business posed by contacting other potential bidders before announcing any transaction and the best process for maximizing stockholder value if the Company were to be sold. These potential risks and considerations included the fact that Blackstone might be able to realize more value from the business than other potential acquirers and thereby pay a higher price to acquire the Company due to, among other reasons, Blackstone’s low cost of capital, substantial available capital and interest in multifamily properties located in the Sunbelt region; the limited universe of other potential third parties with the financial ability to acquire the Company without obtaining financing from third parties in light of the amount of cash required to acquire all of our common and preferred stock; the fact that the large amount of our preferred stock and debt could negatively impact the price for our common stock that other bidders may be willing to pay; and concerns that soliciting additional potential bidders could result in market leaks and rumors regarding a potential transaction which would disrupt our business relationships and risk employee turnover, as well as lead to turnover in our stockholder base and potential stock price volatility. Following this discussion, the directors determined that expediting any transaction process would be important to minimize risks to the Company, protect its business and maximize stockholder value, but that the Company should solicit interest from other potential bidders, either prior to or following signing a definitive merger agreement, in order to maximize shareholder value. After discussion, our board of directors determined to explore a potential transaction with Blackstone and authorized the Company to enter into a confidentiality agreement with Blackstone and provide it with due diligence materials so that Blackstone could provide a proposal with more specific terms. Our board decided that Goldman Sachs should conduct negotiations with Blackstone under the direction of the directors, and instructed Goldman Sachs to inform Blackstone that the Company was prepared to engage on a potential transaction with Blackstone. Our board also directed members of management to refrain from having discussions with Blackstone regarding the roles or compensation, if any, of management following the closing of a negotiated transaction. Following the January 21, 2022 board of directors meeting, our management team prepared an updated version of our five-year projections for 2022 through 2026, reflecting the 2022 budget and 2021 actual data (the “financial projections”), which are discussed in more detail under “-Unaudited Prospective Financial Information”. On January 24, 2022, as directed by our board of directors, a representative of Goldman Sachs called Mr. Werner and indicated that our board of directors was interested in continuing discussions regarding the terms of a potential transaction. Mr. Werner indicated that Blackstone expected to pay a meaningful premium to our common stock trading price, but did not provide a specific price or other terms. The representative of Goldman Sachs indicated that our board of directors was considering whether, if discussions with Blackstone progressed, to contact additional potential bidders prior to entering into any transaction. Mr. Werner indicated that Blackstone was not 33 interested in participating in a pre-signing market check. Its willingness to pay a meaningful premium assumed the Company would not be concurrently negotiating with other parties. The Company would, however, be able to solicit other bids during a post-signing “go-shop” period where there would be a low termination fee payable if the Company accepted another bid. On January 24, 2022, Blackstone announced its agreement to acquire Resource REIT, Inc. (“Resource”) for $14.75 per share in an all-cash transaction valued at approximately $3.7 billion. Resource owns various multifamily properties located in the Sunbelt region. On January 26, 2022, Mr. Isakson, Paul Cullen, the Company’s Executive Vice President, Investor Relations, and Gavriel Kahane, the chief executive officer of Arkhouse, met by videoconference to discuss Arkhouse’s intentions with respect to the Company. During the conversation, Mr. Kahane noted that he believed that the Company was too small, had too much preferred stock and debt, should consider selling its grocery-anchored retail assets and use the proceeds to redeem outstanding preferred stock, and should broaden its public disclosure. Mr. Kahane acknowledged that the Company had already made substantial progress on several of these initiatives. Mr. Kahane stated that if ongoing conversations with the Company were constructive that Arkhouse may withdraw its board nominations. On January 30, 2022, Blackstone entered into a confidentiality agreement with the Company, which contained a customary “standstill” provision that prevented Blackstone from, among other things, making a proposal with respect to an acquisition of the Company except on a confidential basis to the Company. Thereafter, on January 31, 2022, we opened a virtual data room and thereafter Blackstone engaged in due diligence. Throughout January and until the merger agreement was signed, representatives of Goldman Sachs had multiple discussions with representatives of Blackstone regarding its due diligence review of the Company and its business. On February 2, 2022, Mr. Cullen emailed Mr. Kahane to schedule a meeting on February 15, 2022 between Messrs. Murphy, Isakson, Cullen and Kahane to follow up on the matters discussed on January 26, 2022; however, the Company requested to reschedule the meeting on February 14, 2022 due to some personal conflicts that arose shortly before the meeting. On February 6, 2022, Mr. Werner notified a representative of Goldman Sachs that Blackstone intended to provide a proposal later that week or early the following week. Also during the week of February 7, 2022, following a request by Blackstone, Blackstone conducted site visits. On February 8, 2022, representatives of Goldman Sachs received telephonic inquiries from a large private investment firm primarily focused on global real estate (“Party A”) and a publicly traded REIT that owns multifamily communities (“Party B”). Each of those inquiries indicated a general interest in exploring a potential acquisition of the Company, but did not include any specific terms. Goldman Sachs notified our management and outside counsel of these inquiries shortly thereafter, and Mr. Murphy subsequently informed Mr. McLure. The Company determined not to respond to these inquiries until our board of directors had an opportunity to consider them and the Company’s response. On February 9, 2022, representatives of Blackstone, our management team and representatives of Goldman Sachs participated in a due diligence call. On February 9, 2022, after the close of trading on the NYSE, Bloomberg News published an article reporting that the Company was exploring options including a full or partial sale after receiving inbound interest from potential acquirors (the “Bloomberg Article”). On February 9, 2022, the closing price of our common stock was $17.96 per share. Later in the day on February 9, 2022, a representative of the Company received an email from a representative of Party A indicating an interest in any strategic alternatives that the Company might be exploring. Party A did not provide any specific terms of a potential transaction. Mr. Murphy notified Mr. McLure of the email from Party A. The Company determined not to respond to this email until our board of directors had an opportunity to consider the recent inquiries and the Company’s response. On February 10, 2022, representatives of Blackstone called representatives of Goldman Sachs and indicated that Blackstone had substantially completed its business due diligence and would like to acquire the Company at a proposed purchase price of $23.50 per share of common stock in cash (representing an approximate 31% premium 34 to the $17.96 per share unaffected closing price of our common stock on February 9, 2022, the date of the Bloomberg Article, and a 36% premium to the trailing 30-day volume weighted average trading price (or VWAP) through such date). The proposal assumed that the Company would declare only one additional quarterly dividend of $0.175 per share of common stock prior to closing. Mr. Werner noted that Blackstone had received all necessary internal approvals to make its proposal, would proceed without any financing contingency and was prepared to move quickly to complete its confirmatory due diligence and negotiate and finalize a merger agreement as soon as February 14, 2022. Mr. Werner indicated that Blackstone’s proposal assumed there would not be a pre-signing market check. He offered the Company a go-shop provision, which would permit the Company to solicit alternative proposals during the 30-day period following the signing of a merger agreement. The go-shop would be paired with a lower termination fee (equal to 1.7% of the value of our common and preferred stock (approximately $52 million)) payable if we terminated the merger agreement to enter into a superior transaction with a party making a proposal during the go-shop period and a higher termination fee (equal to 3.25% of the value of our common and preferred stock (approximately $100 million)) thereafter, along with matching rights if any superior proposal were received. Blackstone’s proposal also contemplated a reverse termination fee of 9% of the value of our common and preferred stock (approximately $275 million) payable by Blackstone in certain circumstances as an exclusive remedy with no right for the Company to obtain specific performance. In order to move expeditiously given the Bloomberg Article, Mr. Werner conveyed that Blackstone was prepared to use the fully negotiated agreement from Blackstone’s recently announced acquisition of Resource as a precedent agreement for the proposed transaction with the Company. The representative of Goldman Sachs informed Mr. Werner that the Company would revert after discussing the proposal with our board of directors. Also on February 10, 2022, Mr. Murphy received a text message from a representative of a publicly traded REIT that owns multifamily communities (“Party C”) indicating that Party C would be interested in learning more from the Company. No specific terms were provided. Mr. Murphy subsequently briefed Mr. McLure regarding both Blackstone’s indication of interest and the communication from Party C. The Company determined not to respond to the text message from Party C until our board of directors had an opportunity to consider the recent inquiries and the Company’s response. On February 11, 2022, our board of directors was provided a letter from Goldman Sachs with respect to certain relationships with Blackstone, which we refer to as the “Goldman Sachs Disclosure Letter”. On February 12, 2022, our board of directors held a meeting, with members of our management team and representatives from Goldman Sachs, V&E and K&S in attendance. During the meeting, representatives of V&E reviewed the directors’ duties under Maryland law in connection with a potential acquisition of the Company, and our board of directors received an update from representatives of Goldman Sachs on the discussions with Blackstone since the last meeting of our board of directors on January 21, 2022 and the inquiries from Party A, Party B and Party C. Representatives of Goldman Sachs and K&S described the terms of Blackstone’s proposal. Our management team also reviewed with our board of directors the financial projections. Representatives of Goldman Sachs discussed with our board of directors their preliminary financial analysis of the Company, as well as Goldman Sachs’ review of strategic alternatives that might be available to the Company, including remaining as an independent public company or selling certain or all of our grocery-anchored retail assets. A discussion ensued among the directors, management, our outside counsel and financial advisor regarding, among other things: risks and considerations related to each of the strategic alternatives; opportunities to grow our business, improve leverage and become more profitable; challenges that we face and that could arise in the future; the cost of obtaining capital; reasons why Blackstone might be able to realize more value from the business than another bidder and thereby pay a higher price to acquire the Company, including Blackstone’s low cost of capital, substantial available capital and interest in multifamily properties located in the Sunbelt region; and amount of capital needed to acquire all of our common and preferred stock for cash. Our board of directors discussed with management and our advisors the best process for maximizing stockholder value if the Company were to be sold, including whether a competitive bidding process would yield a higher price than Blackstone’s proposal with a go-shop provision, as well as benefits and risks to the Company and its business posed by engaging with Party A, Party B or Party C or contacting other potential bidders before announcing any transaction, including the risk that engaging with or contacting other potential bidders prior to signing a definitive agreement with Blackstone could jeopardize the availability of Blackstone’s proposal. Our board of directors also discussed with its advisors the benefits of a “go- shop” provision that would permit the Company to 35 entertain potentially superior proposals from other bidders while having a binding contract with Blackstone in the event that a merger agreement was ultimately executed with Blackstone and the impact that the reduced company termination fee during the go-shop period proposed by Blackstone might have on other interested parties and their willingness to submit a superior proposal. Our board of directors also discussed with management and our advisors other potential risks and considerations that included: the limited universe of potential third parties with the financial ability to acquire the Company in light of the amount of cash required to acquire all of our common and preferred stock without obtaining financing from third parties; concerns about the recent media reports and rumors that the Company was exploring a possible partial or full sale of the company disrupting our business relationships and risking employee turnover; and indicative capitalization rates from recent transactions in the REIT industry. The directors unanimously agreed that the transaction process should be expedited to minimize risks to the Company, protect its business and maximize stockholder value and determined to further discuss next steps the following day. On February 13, 2022, our board of directors held a meeting, with members of our management team and representatives from Goldman Sachs, V&E and K&S in attendance. The directors discussed strategic alternatives that might be available to the Company other than a sale of the Company, including a sale of its grocery-anchored retail assets and remaining an independent public company, and risks and considerations related to each. Our board of directors concluded that it was not in the best interests of the Company or our stockholders to pursue any of the strategic alternatives other than continuing to consider the Blackstone proposal or remaining an independent public company. Our board of directors next discussed with management and our advisors, among other items, the Company’s financial projections, the Company’s recent share price and the premia of the Blackstone proposal to various Company common stock prices, as further described in the section entitled “-Opinion of Our Financial Advisor- Summary of Financial Analyses”, FFO trading multiples of comparable multifamily and retail public REITs, potential future Company common stock prices based on these multiples and the financial projections, the present value of potential future stock prices and dividends compared to the Blackstone proposal, including how different assumptions affected such potential future Company common stock prices and the present value of potential future stock prices and dividends, and other financial matters related to the Company. Our board of directors also discussed with its advisors an illustrative timeline if it were to proceed with further discussions with Blackstone. After discussing the terms of Blackstone’s proposal and various potential responses, our board of directors unanimously agreed that it was in the best interests of the Company to continue discussions with Blackstone. Our board of directors then discussed the best process for maximizing stockholder value if the Company were to be sold, including whether to first solicit additional potential bidders or sign a merger agreement with Blackstone that included a go-shop provision. Our board of directors further discussed the benefits of a “go-shop” provision that would permit the Company to entertain potentially superior proposals from other bidders in an orderly process while having a binding contract with Blackstone and determined that a “go-shop” provision could be beneficial so long as the termination fee during the go-shop period was sufficiently low so as not to deter other bidders. Our board of directors also noted that Party A, Party B and Party C had not indicated that they had done any work analyzing a transaction at that point, and on the other hand, Blackstone had completed its due diligence and was prepared to sign a merger agreement within the next few days if the parties could agree to terms of the transaction. Our board of directors discussed with our advisors the likelihood of Party A, Party B and Party C submitting a proposal with better terms than the terms of Blackstone’s proposal, timing considerations relating to such possible proposals and the terms thereof including the potential form of consideration and the likelihood of a financing contingency. The directors also discussed that engaging with Party A, Party B or Party C, or soliciting additional potential bidders, could result in Blackstone changing the terms in its proposal or electing to disengage from negotiations for a potential transaction in light of Blackstone’s stated unwillingness to participate in a pre-signing market check. Our board of directors unanimously agreed that it would not be in the best interests of the Company to pause discussions with Blackstone to allow time to engage with Party A, Party B or Party C or solicit additional potential bidders so long as any potential deal with Blackstone included a post-signing go-shop with a low termination fee. As a result, our board of directors determined that Mr. Murphy and representatives of the Company should not contact Party A, Party B or Party C until the Company had entered into a binding merger agreement with Blackstone containing a go-shop provision and low termination fees. Following further discussion, our board of directors determined that it was in the best interests of the Company and its stockholders to continue to engage in discussions with Blackstone and directed a representative of Goldman Sachs to present Blackstone with a counterproposal on the following terms: a purchase price of $25.00 per share of common stock in cash (representing an approximate 39% premium to the $17.96 per share unaffected closing price of our common stock on February 9, 2022, the date of the Bloomberg Article, and an approximate 41% premium to 36 the trailing 30-day VWAP through such date); the Company would have the right to declare only one additional quarterly dividend of $0.175 per share of the common stock prior to closing of the transaction; a 30-day “go-shop” provision with a two-tier termination fee consisting of a termination fee of $25 million (equal to 0.5% of the Company’s enterprise value) if the Company terminated the merger agreement to accept a superior proposal in connection with the go-shop and a termination fee of $50 million (equal to 0.9% of the Company’s enterprise value) thereafter; and a reverse termination fee of $300 million equal to 5.4% of the Company’s enterprise value) payable by Blackstone in certain circumstances as an exclusive remedy and no right for the Company to obtain specific performance. Given the recent media reports and market rumors that the Company was exploring a possible partial or full sale of the company, the directors continued to be of the view that expediting the transaction process would be critical to minimizing risks to the Company and protecting its business and maximizing stockholder value. Mr. McLure, as our lead independent director, noted that our board of directors needed to understand Blackstone’s thoughts about retaining the Company platform and employees in connection with finalizing a transaction, assuming that the Company and Blackstone could agree to the price and other material terms of the transaction. The directors unanimously agreed that, if the transaction progressed, Mr. McLure should discuss Blackstone’s intentions. The directors and a representative of V&E also discussed options to handle future negotiations with Blackstone given the pace of the transaction. Our board of directors also discussed the interests of our directors and executive officers in the mergers that are different from, or in addition to, those of our stockholders generally, as discussed under “-Interests of our Directors and Executive Officers in the Mergers”. Following this discussion, our board of directors formed a committee of directors consisting of Mr. Murphy as well as independent directors Mr. McLure, John Cannon, Sara Finley and Tim Peterson (the “Transaction Committee”) in order to expeditiously evaluate and handle future negotiations with Blackstone. During this February 13, 2022 meeting, representatives of Goldman Sachs described its qualifications and experience with these types of transactions. Following the departure of the Goldman Sachs representatives from the meeting, our board of directors discussed with management and representatives of V&E and K&S the contemplated engagement of Goldman Sachs as our financial advisor, Goldman Sachs’ relationships with Blackstone and the fees to be paid to Goldman Sachs in connection with their engagement. After considering the overall reputation, experience and qualifications of Goldman Sachs, as well as Goldman Sachs’ knowledge of multifamily and retail property asset classes and broader real estate market and the Company’s business and properties in particular, and information provided by Goldman Sachs in the Goldman Sachs Disclosure Letter as discussed under “- Opinions of Our Financial Advisors,” our board of directors unanimously approved the engagement of Goldman Sachs as our financial advisor with respect to a potential sale of the Company and authorized management and our outside counsel to finalize the engagement letter with Goldman Sachs. On February 13, 2022, as directed by our board of directors, representatives of Goldman Sachs orally communicated to representatives of Blackstone our counterproposal. Later that day, Blackstone’s outside counsel, Simpson Thacher & Bartlett LLP (“Simpson Thacher”), sent to our outside counsel, K&S and V&E, drafts of a merger agreement, limited guaranty and equity commitment letter. The draft merger agreement contemplated that, among other things: the Company would merge with and into a wholly owned subsidiary of an affiliate of Blackstone and another wholly owned subsidiary of an affiliate of Blackstone would merge with and into the Partnership, with the respective holders of shares of the Company’s common stock and units in the Partnership to receive the same cash consideration; the Company would be able to solicit proposals during a 30-day go-shop period with the ability to continue to negotiate during the subsequent 10-day period with a bidder who made a qualified proposal during the go-shop period; and, subject to certain exceptions, the Company would be permitted flexibility to continue to operate in the ordinary course of business prior to closing. Between February 13, 2022 and February 15, 2022, we, with the assistance of K&S and V&E, and Blackstone, with the assistance of Simpson Thacher, negotiated the terms of the merger agreement and related documentation. The negotiations covered various aspects of the transaction, including, among other things: the treatment the preferred stock and warrants, the representations and warranties to be made by the parties, the restriction on the conduct of the Company’s business until completion of the transaction, the conditions to completion of the mergers, our ability to participate in discussions and negotiations with third parties relating to unsolicited proposals, the right of our board of directors to change its recommendation that stockholders approve the merger in response to a superior proposal or otherwise, our right to terminate the merger agreement to accept a superior proposal under certain conditions, the other termination provisions and the triggers of the termination fee payable by us, and the 37 provisions regarding our equity awards, employee benefit plans, retention, severance and other compensation matters. Blackstone also continued to complete its confirmatory due diligence. On February 14, 2022, Mr. Werner orally communicated a revised proposal to a representative of Goldman Sachs. Blackstone accepted the Company’s February 13, 2022 proposal, except that the termination fee payable by the Company would be $100 million (rather than $50 million as the Company had proposed) if the Company terminated the merger agreement to accept a superior proposal after the 30-day go-shop period (or the subsequent 10-day period to enter into a superior proposal with a bidder who made a qualified proposal during the go-shop period). Blackstone also reiterated that it expected the parties to work expeditiously and expressed its desire to sign a merger agreement by 8:00 a.m. on February 16, 2022. Later in the day on February 14, 2022, the Transaction Committee met with representatives of Goldman Sachs, V&E and K&S. A representative of Goldman Sachs reviewed Blackstone’s proposal with the Transaction Committee, noting that Blackstone assumed that the Company would not contact other parties prior to signing a merger agreement with Blackstone. The Transaction Committee discussed the terms of Blackstone’s latest proposal and unanimously agreed to respond by requesting a lower termination fee of $80 million (rather than Blackstone’s proposed $100 million) payable by the Company if the Company terminated the merger agreement to accept a superior proposal after the expiration of the 30-day go-shop period (or the subsequent 10-day period to enter into a superior proposal with a bidder who made a qualified proposal during the go-shop period). Following the meeting, at the direction of the Transaction Committee, a representative of Goldman Sachs orally communicated our counterproposal to Blackstone, which Blackstone accepted. With the parties having agreed upon the purchase price and the other material terms of the proposed transaction, Mr. McLure and Ms. Finley discussed with Mr. Werner Blackstone’s general thoughts on the Company’s platform and employees. During this discussion, Mr. Werner articulated that Blackstone was impressed by the Company’s platform, including the Company’s people and processes, and that the platform was an important consideration in determining to acquire the Company. No specific employees or employment terms were discussed. Later on February 14, 2022, a representative of Party A sent an email to Goldman Sachs indicating an interest in exploring a potential acquisition of the Company without specifying any terms. Goldman Sachs notified our management and outside counsel of this inquiry shortly thereafter and Mr. Murphy informed Mr. McLure of this inquiry that same day. The Company determined to not respond to this email until our board of directors had an opportunity to consider this inquiry and the Company’s response. On February 15, 2022, our board of directors held a meeting with members of our management team and representatives from Goldman Sachs, V&E and K&S in attendance. Mr. McLure and Ms. Finley updated our board of directors regarding their discussion with Blackstone the prior day. A representative of Goldman Sachs updated our board of directors on the changes to the key economic terms in Blackstone’s proposal since the last board of directors meeting and also informed our board of directors about Party A’s inquiry. Our board of directors asked questions and engaged in discussion. A representative of Goldman Sachs presented to our board of directors Goldman Sachs’ preliminary financial analysis of the common stock consideration. A representative of K&S provided a summary of the merger agreement and other transaction documentation and noted that they were substantially complete, and representatives of K&S and V&E noted that it would be possible to sign the merger agreement before the market opened on February 16, 2022. Around 10:30 p.m. on February 15, 2022, Party A sent the Company an unsolicited letter that contained a non-binding proposal from Party A relating to a potential acquisition of the Company by Party A for $29.25 per share of Company common stock, without specifying any additional terms. The letter stated that Party A was ready to confirm its price within five calendar days of receipt of non-public property level and corporate information, and after economic terms were agreed, it would need an unspecified period to complete confirmatory due diligence. While the letter stated that the proposal was not contingent on financing, it indicated that a portion of the funds for the transaction may be provided by an opportunity fund sponsored by Party A. The letter said that Party A was fully authorized to pursue the transaction on the terms of the proposal, but added that it anticipated obtaining final approval from its investment committee upon completion of confirmatory diligence and agreement with the Company on the material transaction terms. Later that evening, the Transaction Committee held a meeting with representatives of our management team and representatives of Goldman Sachs, V&E and K&S to discuss the proposal from Party A. The group reviewed and 38 discussed the potential benefits, risks and other considerations involved in engaging with Party A and potentially other parties prior to entering into a merger agreement with Blackstone, including those discussed at prior meetings of our board of directors, recent geopolitical risks, related market volatility, that Blackstone had completed all of its due diligence, Blackstone and the Company had agreed upon all financial and other material terms of a transaction and were imminently prepared to execute the merger agreement, and that engaging with Party A or other potential bidders could jeopardize the availability of Blackstone’s proposal in light of its stated unwillingness to participate in a pre-signing market check. The Transaction Committee also considered that, if viable, Party A’s proposal exceeded the price per share of the Blackstone transaction, but that Party A’s letter was only a non-binding indication of interest, that Party A had not yet conducted any non-public due diligence on the Company, that Party A indicated it would need five days to confirm its price after it received non-public property level and corporate information and then an unspecified period for confirmatory due diligence, that Party A’s offer was subject to and could be altered upon completion of due diligence, and that it anticipated obtaining final approval from its investment committee upon completion of confirmatory diligence and agreement with the Company on the material transaction terms. The Transaction Committee also discussed that at least a portion of the proceeds associated with the Party A proposal may be sourced from an opportunity fund sponsored by Party A, indicating a higher cost of capital and, as a consequence, that Party A could reduce its price. The Transaction Committee also discussed with our advisors the potential opportunity for the Company to continue soliciting a superior proposal from Party A and other interested parties following the signing of a merger agreement with Blackstone pursuant to the go-shop mechanism. The Transaction Committee believed that the go-shop process would provide Party A and other interested parties the opportunity to conduct due diligence on the Company and make a binding proposal if Party A or any other party desired to do so. In particular, the Transaction Committee observed that the $25 million company termination fee applicable to qualified proposals made during the go-shop period, which represented approximately $0.42 per share of common stock on a fully-diluted basis as of February 16, 2022, was low compared to the size of the proposed transaction with Blackstone, the indication of interest from Party A, and similar transactions involving other public companies, and not likely to preclude or discourage Party A or other interested parties from submitting a superior proposal. The group also discussed the ability for the Company to maintain control through a go-shop process that would allow a market check to maximize shareholder value, the limited universe of potential third parties with the financial ability to acquire the Company in light of the amount of cash required to acquire all of our common and preferred stock with no financing contingency and concerns about the recent market leak and rumors that the Company was exploring strategic alternatives including a possible partial or full sale disrupting the Company’s business relationships and risking employee turnover. Following discussion, after considering the certainty represented by Blackstone’s $25.00 per share fully financed proposal, the risk that Blackstone could withdraw or adversely modify its proposal, the fact that Party A may not make a definitive proposal and our directors’ belief that Party A and others would have the opportunity to engage with the Company during the go-shop period to pursue a competing transaction, the Transaction Committee unanimously recommended that our board of directors approve the merger agreement with Blackstone and encourage Party A to participate in the go-shop process. As a result of this discussion, the Transaction Committee determined that Mr. Murphy and representatives of the Company should not reach out to Party A until following the start of the go-shop period. On February 16, 2022, our board of directors held a meeting with members of our management team and representatives from Goldman Sachs, V&E and K&S in attendance. Mr. Murphy and a representative of Goldman Sachs reviewed the non-binding proposal received from Party A and Mr. McLure noted that the Transaction Committee had met the night before and unanimously recommended that our board of directors approve the merger agreement with Blackstone and advise Party A to participate in the go-shop process. Our board of directors discussed with representatives of K&S and V&E the process for Party A to participate in the go-shop process and the considerations discussed by the Transaction Committee. Representatives of our management, Goldman Sachs and K&S then updated our board of directors on changes to the merger agreement since the last board of directors meeting and noted that the merger agreement and other transaction documentation were ready to be signed. A representative of V&E then reminded the members of our board of directors of their duties under Maryland law. A representative of V&E described a proposed amendment to our bylaws that would make specified state and federal courts in Maryland the sole and exclusive forum for litigation relating to our internal affairs, including stockholder derivative suits and alleged breaches of duties owed to stockholders, and the federal district courts in the United States the sole and exclusive forum for litigation arising under the Securities Act. Following this discussion, a representative of Goldman Sachs presented to our board of directors the Goldman Sachs’ financial analysis of the common stock consideration and rendered to our board of directors Goldman Sachs’ oral opinion, subsequently confirmed in its written opinion dated February 16, 2022, to the effect that, as of such date, and based upon and 39 subject to the factors and assumptions set forth in Goldman Sachs’ written opinion, the $25.00 in cash per share of common stock to be paid to the holders (other than Parent and its affiliates) of the shares of common stock pursuant to the merger agreement was fair, from a financial point of view, to such holders. A representative of V&E then reviewed the proposed resolutions prepared for the proposed transaction, including the engagement of KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc. as an additional financial advisor to the Company. Following these presentations and discussions, and other discussions by our board of directors concerning, among other things, the matters described below under “-Reasons for the Mergers,” including our board of directors’ belief that the mergers are more favorable to our stockholders than other strategic transactions available to the Company, including remaining as an independent public company, our board of directors unanimously determined the mergers advisable, approved the mergers on the terms and conditions set forth in the merger agreement and resolved to recommend the approval of the mergers by our stockholders. Following the board of directors’ meeting, we contacted representatives of Blackstone to advise them that our board of directors had unanimously approved the proposed transaction. During the early morning on February 16, 2022, the Company, affiliates of Blackstone and the other parties thereto executed and delivered the merger agreement. The Company issued a press release publicly announcing the mergers and execution of the merger agreement before the opening of the market on February 16, 2022. The press release announcing the transaction also noted that the merger agreement included a 30-day “go- shop” period that would expire on March 18, 2022. Later in the day on February 16, 2022, at the direction of our board of directors, representatives of Goldman Sachs began contacting Party A, Party B, Party C and other potential counterparties that might consider entering into an alternative transaction with the Company. In addition, on February 17, 2022, Mr. Murphy sent an e-mail to Party A acknowledging its non-binding proposal from February 15, 2022, notifying it that the Company had begun its go-shop process pursuant to the merger agreement and welcoming Party A’s participation in the process. During the go- shop period, Goldman Sachs contacted 23 potential counterparties (including Party A, Party B and Party C), consisting of five strategic parties and 18 financial sponsor parties, and received inbound inquiries from two additional potential counterparties (one strategic and one financial). Of these 25 parties, nine, including Party A, Party B and Party C, entered into a confidentiality agreement with the Company. Each of the parties that entered into a confidentiality agreement received access to the virtual data room containing non-public information about the Company. Other than the proposal submitted by Party A on February 15, 2022, none of these parties submitted a proposal to acquire the Company. Party A entered into a confidentiality agreement with the Company on February 22, 2022 and received access to the virtual data room on such date. On March 4, 2022, representatives of Party A attended a due diligence call with Mr. Murphy, other members of our management and representatives of Goldman Sachs. Later that same day, members of our management and representatives of Goldman Sachs and K&S attended a legal due diligence call with representatives of Party A and its outside counsel. On March 15, 2022, a representative of Party A informed representatives of Goldman Sachs that Party A intended to submit a comprehensive bid package to the Company that would specify the economic terms of Party A’s offer and include definitive transaction documents, including debt commitment letters. On that same day, representatives of Party A’s outside counsel contacted K&S and conveyed the same message, and subsequently sent K&S a draft of Party A’s proposed merger agreement, equity commitment letter and limited guaranty. Party A’s proposed merger agreement did not specify the consideration to be paid to the holders of our common stock and contemplated that the transaction would be financed through a combination of equity financing from an investment vehicle sponsored by Party A and debt financing from third party lenders in the form of senior secured bridge term loans and mortgage and mezzanine loans on terms that would be set forth in debt commitment letters. Party A did not provide debt commitment letters or otherwise describe the amount or terms of it proposed debt financing or identify the lenders who would provide the debt. Party A’s proposed equity commitment letter did not specify a commitment amount and funding of the equity was conditioned upon the receipt of debt financing contemplated by the debt commitment letters. On March 16, 2022, representatives of Goldman Sachs had a call with representatives of Party A during which the Party A representatives indicated that they were aware of the upcoming expiration of the go-shop period on 40 March 18, 2022 and indicated that they expected to touch base with Goldman Sachs on March 17, 2022 to provide an update on Party A’s internal approval process, but that a formal offer would likely not be submitted until March 18, 2022. Representatives of Goldman Sachs notified the Company of these discussions, and the Company scheduled a board meeting for March 18, 2022 to discuss any offer that may be received from Party A and any other developments that may occur. Later on March 16, 2022, K&S, on behalf of the Company, sent comments on Party A’s proposed merger agreement, equity commitment letter and limited guaranty to Party A’s outside counsel. At 12:00 p.m. on March 17, 2022, Party A’s outside counsel met with members of our management and representatives of K&S to discuss outstanding due diligence matters. Later that day, representatives of Party A contacted representatives of Goldman Sachs to discuss Party A’s proposed sources of capital for the transaction. The representatives of Party A noted that the size and terms of Party A’s contemplated senior secured bridge term loans would result in unfavorable potential investment returns to Party A in a transaction. In order to mitigate this issue, the representatives of Party A noted that Party A would need to enter into an “equity bridge” instrument which would incrementally reduce the size of the bridge term loans if and to the extent that an investment vehicle affiliated with Party A’s sponsor received equity capital from third-party investors that was allocated to the transaction. In response to a question from representatives of Goldman Sachs on whether Party A could avoid this issue by instead using additional sources of available equity capital, the representatives of Party A explained that investment vehicles affiliated with Party A’s sponsor did not have sufficient committed capital at such time. A few hours later, representatives of Party A notified representatives of Goldman Sachs that Party A would not be submitting a proposal. The Party A representatives noted that, although Party A wished to submit a proposal, it was not able to obtain the necessary financing on terms that would permit it to pay more than the $25.00 per share of common stock under the Blackstone merger agreement. The representatives of Party A explained that given the recent deterioration in the debt and financial markets, and the fact that spreads on mortgage and mezzanine loans had widened significantly since it had submitted its non-binding proposal, Party A could not obtain sufficient financing on terms that would allow it to pay more than $25.00 per share. Representatives of Goldman Sachs promptly informed Mr. Murphy and the Company of this communication. The Company decided to hold the board meeting scheduled for March 18, 2022 to provide an opportunity for our board of directors to discuss any other developments that may occur prior to the expiry of the go-shop period. On March 18, 2022, our board of directors held a meeting, with members of our management team and representatives of Goldman Sachs, V&E and K&S in attendance. Representatives of Goldman Sachs provided an overview of the go-shop process undertaken, including the broad solicitation of various strategic parties and financial sponsors, and the recent discussions with Party A. The Company issued a press release and filed a Current Report on Form 8-K prior to the market open on March 21, 2022, announcing that the go- shop period expired at 11:59 p.m., New York City time, on March 18, 2022. Reasons for the Mergers In reaching its unanimous decision to determine and declare the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, including the mergers, to be advisable and in our and our stockholders’ best interests and to approve the execution, delivery and performance of the merger agreement and the consummation of the transactions contemplated thereby, and to resolve to recommend that the holders of common stock approve the merger proposal, the board of directors consulted with our senior management team, as well as our financial and legal advisors, and considered a number of factors, including the following material factors which the board of directors viewed as supporting its decision: •the current and historical trading prices of shares of our common stock, and the fact that the merger consideration of $25.00 per share in cash represents a premium of approximately 39% to the unaffected closing price of $17.96 on February 9, 2022, the last trading day prior to the Bloomberg article reporting that the Company was exploring options including a full or partial sale after receiving inbound interest, and a premium of approximately 60% to the 90-day volume-weighted average price through that date; •the fact that the merger consideration was the result of arm’s-length negotiations and that the merger consideration of $25.00 per share exceeded Blackstone’s initial anticipated range as of December 7, 2021 of $4 to $5 per share above our common stock’s market price (implying an anticipated range of $17.56 to $18.56 per share based on the closing price of $13.56 per share on December 6, 2021); 41

Representatives of Goldman Sachs notified the Company of these discussions, and the Company scheduled a board meeting for March 18, 2022 to discuss any offer that may be received from Party A and any other developments that may occur. Later on March 16, 2022, K&S, on behalf of the Company, sent comments on Party A’s proposed merger agreement, equity commitment letter and limited guaranty to Party A’s outside counsel. At 12:00 p.m. on March 17, 2022, Party A’s outside counsel met with members of our management and representatives of K&S to discuss outstanding due diligence matters. Later that day, representatives of Party A contacted representatives of Goldman Sachs to discuss Party A’s proposed sources of capital for the transaction. The representatives of Party A noted that the size and terms of Party A’s contemplated senior secured bridge term loans would result in unfavorable potential investment returns to Party A in a transaction. In response to a question from representatives of Goldman Sachs on whether Party A could avoid this issue by instead using additional sources of available equity capital, the representatives of Party A explained that investment vehicles affiliated with Party A’s sponsor did not have sufficient committed capital at such time. A few hours later, representatives of Party A notified representatives of Goldman Sachs that Party A would not be submitting a proposal. The Party A representatives noted that, although Party A wished to submit a proposal, it was not able to obtain the necessary financing on terms that would permit it to pay more than the $25.00 per share of common stock under the Blackstone merger agreement. Representatives of Goldman Sachs promptly informed Mr. Murphy and the Company of this communication. The Company decided to hold the board meeting scheduled for March 18, 2022 to provide an opportunity for our board of directors to discuss any other developments that may occur prior to the expiry of the go-shop period. On March 18, 2022, our board of directors held a meeting, with members of our management team and representatives of Goldman Sachs, V&E and K&S in attendance. Representatives of Goldman Sachs provided an overview of the go-shop process undertaken, including the broad solicitation of various strategic parties and financial sponsors, and the recent discussions with Party A. The Company issued a press release and filed a Current Report on Form 8-K prior to the market open on March 21, 2022, announcing that the go- shop period expired at 11:59 p.m., New York City time, on March 18, 2022. Reasons for the Mergers In reaching its unanimous decision to determine and declare the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, including the mergers, to be advisable and in our and our stockholders’ best interests and to approve the execution, delivery and performance of the merger agreement and the consummation of the transactions contemplated thereby, and to resolve to recommend that the holders of common stock approve the merger proposal, the board of directors consulted with our senior management team, as well as our financial and legal advisors, and considered a number of factors, including the following material factors which the board of directors viewed as supporting its decision: •the current and historical trading prices of shares of our common stock, and the fact that the merger consideration of $25.00 per share in cash represents a premium of approximately 39% to the unaffected closing price of $17.96 on February 9, 2022, the last trading day prior to the Bloomberg article reporting that the Company was exploring options including a full or partial sale after receiving inbound interest, and a premium of approximately 60% to the 90-day volume-weighted average price through that date; •the fact that the merger consideration was the result of arm’s-length negotiations and that the merger consideration of $25.00 per share exceeded Blackstone’s initial anticipated range as of December 7, 2021 of $4 to $5 per share above our common stock’s market price (implying an anticipated range of $17.56 to $18.56 per share based on the closing price of $13.56 per share on December 6, 2021); 41 •our board of directors’ belief that, in light of Blackstone’s low cost of capital, substantial available capital and interest in multifamily properties located in the Sunbelt region, Blackstone was the possible acquiror likely to offer the highest price for the Company; •our board of directors’ belief that there exists a limited universe of potential third parties with the financial ability to acquire the Company without obtaining financing from third parties in light of the amount of cash required to acquire all of our common and preferred stock; and that the large amount of our preferred stock and debt could negatively impact the price for our common stock that bidders may be able to pay; •our board of directors’ belief that contacting other potential bidders before announcing a transaction with Blackstone given these circumstances would result in significant risks to the Company and its business, including concerns that market leaks and rumors regarding a potential transaction would disrupt our business relationships and risk employee turnover, as well as lead to turnover in our stockholder base and potential stock price volatility; •our board of directors’ belief, in light of Blackstone’s stated unwillingness to participate in a pre-signing market check, that engaging with Party A would delay and jeopardize a transaction with Blackstone that was imminently ready to be entered into at the time of receipt of Party A’s proposal, taking into account the fact that Party A’s proposal was non-binding, that Party A had not yet conducted any non-public due diligence on the Company, that Party A indicated it would need five days to confirm its price after it received non-public property level and corporate information and then an unspecified period for confirmatory due diligence, that Party A’s offer was subject to and could be altered upon completion of due diligence, that it anticipated obtaining final approval from its investment committee upon completion of confirmatory diligence and agreement with the Company on the material transaction terms, and that at least a portion of the proceeds associated with Party A’s proposal may be sourced from an opportunity fund sponsored by Party A, indicating a higher cost of capital and a risk that Party A could reduce its price; •the Company’s right under the merger agreement, during the 30-day go-shop period, to actively solicit other proposals from, furnish information to and conduct negotiations with, third parties (including Party A) providing an opportunity to determine if a third party is willing to pay a higher value per share than Blackstone; •our right to terminate the merger agreement, under certain circumstances, in order to enter into a definitive agreement providing for the implementation of a superior proposal, upon payment of the company termination payment; •the fact that the lower company termination payment of $25 million during the go-shop period, which represented approximately $0.42 per share of common stock on a fully-diluted basis as of February 16, 2022 and approximately 0.5% of the Company’s enterprise value, and the company termination payment of $80 million following the go-shop period (representing approximately 1.4% of the Company’s enterprise value) were viewed by our board of directors, after consultation with our outside legal counsel and financial advisors, as reasonable under the circumstances, low compared to the size of the proposed transaction with Blackstone, the indication of interest from Party A, and similar transactions involving public companies, and not likely to preclude or discourage Party A or other interested parties from making a superior proposal; •our right after the go-shop period, in certain circumstances in response to unsolicited competing proposals, to furnish information to and conduct negotiations with third parties; •the right of our board of directors under the merger agreement to change, withhold, qualify or withdraw its recommendation that the holders of common stock approve the merger under certain circumstances, subject to payment of the company termination payment if Parent elects to terminate the merger agreement in such circumstances; •the fact that the merger consideration is a fixed cash amount, providing our stockholders with certainty of value and liquidity immediately upon the closing of the merger, in comparison to the risks, uncertainties and longer potential timeline for realizing equivalent or greater value from our business plan for our properties or other possible strategic alternatives (including the sale of our grocery-anchored real estate assets); 42 •the knowledge of our board of directors of the business, operations, financial condition, earnings and prospects of the Company, including its multifamily and grocery-anchored retail assets, as well as its knowledge of the current and prospective environment in which the Company and each of its businesses operate, including economic, market and capital raising conditions; •the accumulation of available equity capital for stabilized multifamily residential real estate assets resulting in low capitalization rates for those assets, with prices for multifamily residential real estate assets being at or near historical highs, strong revenue fundamentals in the multifamily residential real estate market in the Sunbelt region, increasing supply of multifamily residential real estate assets, as well as the possibility of interest rate increases in the future, which our board of directors and management believed made for opportune conditions for a sale transaction; •the risks and uncertainties of remaining a public company owner of our multifamily residential real estate portfolio and/or selling certain of our grocery-anchored retail assets, including the substantial amount of our preferred stock and debt, including significant property level debt, the need to frequently raise capital due to the capital-intensive nature of the Company’s business, the difficulty and cost of obtaining such capital, and the challenges of acquiring multifamily properties on an accretive basis in the current environment; •the belief that the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement are more favorable to our stockholders than other strategic alternatives available to the Company, including after considering the feasibility of such alternatives and the significant risks and uncertainties associated with pursuing such alternatives, including remaining as an independent public company or selling certain or all of our grocery-anchored retail assets; •the expected probability that the mergers would be completed based on, among other things, Blackstone’s substantial available capital, proven ability to complete large acquisition transactions, extensive experience in the real estate industry, the absence of a financing condition and the $300 million parent termination payment payable to the Company if the merger agreement is terminated in certain circumstances (representing approximately 5.4% of the Company’s enterprise value), which payment is guaranteed by BREIT Operating Partnership L.P.; •the financial analysis of Goldman Sachs reviewed and discussed with our board of directors, and the oral opinion of Goldman Sachs, subsequently confirmed in Goldman Sachs’ written opinion dated as of February 16, 2022, to the effect that, as of the date of Goldman Sachs’ written opinion, and based upon and subject to the factors and assumptions set forth in Goldman Sachs’ written opinion, the $25.00 in cash per share of common stock to be paid to the holders (other than Parent and its affiliates) of the shares of common stock pursuant to the merger agreement was fair from a financial point of view to such holders, as more fully described below in the section “-Opinion of Our Financial Advisor”; •the terms and conditions of the merger agreement, which were reviewed by the board of directors with our financial and legal advisors, and the fact that such terms were the product of arm’s-length negotiations between the parties; and •the fact that the merger would be subject to the approval of our stockholders, and our stockholders would be free to reject the merger by voting against the merger for any reason, including if a higher offer were to be made prior to the stockholders’ meeting (in certain cases subject to payment by the Company of an $80 million company termination payment if the Company subsequently were to enter into a definitive agreement relating to, or to consummate, a competing proposal). The board of directors also considered the following potentially negative factors in its consideration of the merger agreement and the merger: •our inability, after 11:59 p.m. (New York City time) on March 18, 2022, to solicit competing proposals and the possibility that the company termination payment payable by us upon the termination of the merger agreement under certain circumstances could discourage other potential bidders, including Party A, from making a competing bid to acquire us; 43 •the fact that, following the mergers, the Company will no longer exist as an independent public company and our existing stockholders will not participate in any future earnings or growth; •the risk that an alternative transaction or different strategic alternative potentially could be more beneficial to our stockholders than the proposed merger with Blackstone; •the fact that the mergers might not be consummated in a timely manner or at all, due to a failure of certain conditions to the closing of the mergers, including the risk that our stockholders do not approve the merger proposal; •the fact that if either of Parent, Merger Sub I, Merger Sub II or Merger Sub III fails, or threatens to fail, to satisfy its obligations under the merger agreement, we are not entitled to specifically enforce the merger agreement or the equity commitment letter, and that our exclusive remedy, available if the merger agreement is terminated in certain circumstances, would be limited to the parent termination payment in the amount of $300 million (the payment of which is guaranteed by BREIT Operating Partnership L.P.); •the restrictions on the conduct of our business prior to the completion of the mergers, which could delay or prevent us from undertaking business opportunities that may arise pending completion of the mergers; •the fact that, under the terms of the merger agreement, the Company is not permitted to make, declare or pay regular quarterly cash dividends on common stock for fiscal quarters after the fiscal quarter ending March 31, 2022; •the fact that the receipt of the cash consideration in the merger would be taxable to our stockholders for U.S. federal income tax purposes; •the fact that, under Maryland law, our stockholders are not entitled to appraisal rights, dissenters’ rights or similar rights of an objecting stockholder in connection with the merger; •the significant costs involved in connection with entering into the merger agreement and completing the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement and the substantial time and effort of management required to consummate the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement and related disruptions to the operation of our business; •the fact that the announcement and pendency of the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, the failure to complete the mergers, and/or actions that the Company may be required, or Parent may be permitted, to take under the merger agreement could have an adverse impact on our existing and prospective business relationships with tenants and other third parties and on our employees; and •the fact that some of our directors and executive officers have interests in the mergers that are different from, or in addition to, our stockholders generally (see “- Interests of Our Directors and Executive Officers in the Merger”). The foregoing discussion of the factors considered by the board of directors is not intended to be exhaustive, but rather includes the material factors considered by the board of directors. In reaching its decision to determine and declare the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, including the mergers, to be advisable and in the best interests of the Company and our stockholders and to approve the execution, delivery and performance of the merger agreement and the consummation of the transactions contemplated thereby, and to resolve to recommend that the holders of common stock approve the merger proposal, the board of directors did not quantify or assign any relative weights to, and did not make specific assessments of, the factors considered, and individual directors may have given different weights to different factors. The board of directors did not reach any specific conclusion with respect to any of the factors or reasons considered. The above factors are not presented in any order of priority. The explanation of the factors and reasoning set forth above contain forward-looking statements and should be read in conjunction with the section of this proxy statement entitled “Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-Looking Statements.” 44 Recommendation of Our Board of Directors Our board of directors has unanimously approved, adopted and declared advisable the merger agreement and determined the merger agreement and the transactions contemplated by the merger agreement, including the mergers, to be advisable and in the best interests of the Company and our stockholders. Our board of directors recommends that you vote “FOR” the merger proposal, “FOR” the advisory compensation proposal and “FOR” the adjournment proposal.
